initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.
+===Postgraduate level===
+After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}, Candidate of Sciences). The seeker should pass three exams (in his/her special field, in a foreign language of his/her choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.  
+
+After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Few (2 to 4) years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}) with obtaining important scientific results, publishing them and writing new thesis would result in the ''Doctor Nauk'' degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}, Doctor of Sciences), but the typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only 1 of 4 ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
+
+''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor (''Docent'') in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in a scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal and higher ones.
+
+Now the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine proposes to change the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.

And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==General information==

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

+==Ukrainian educational system==
+Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukraine's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 
+
+===School level===
+Since 2005, a 12-year school system was introduced in Ukraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (starting at age six), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. There are then 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens.
+
+In the 12th grade students sit the Government Tests or school-leaving exams. The Government tests act like both school-leaving exams and university admission tests. 
+
+By 2009 all who want to join university will have to sit the Government Tests, instead of the other two exams.
+
+===University level===
+The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).
+
+Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("diferentsiyovanyi zalik" – "диференційований залік") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.
+
+There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years), and Master's Degree (5-6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Ukraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.
+
+===Postgraduate level===
+After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}, Candidate of Sciences). The seeker should pass three exams (in his/her special field, in a foreign language of his/her choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.  
+
+After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Few (2 to 4) years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}) with obtaining important scientific results, publishing them and writing new thesis would result in the ''Doctor Nauk'' degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}, Doctor of Sciences), but the typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only 1 of 4 ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
+
+''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor (''Docent'') in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in a scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal and higher ones.
+
+Now the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine proposes to change the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.
+
+===Marks===
+
+Ukrainian universities use traditional 5-grade scale:
+"5" = excellent,
+"4" = good,
+"3" = acceptable,
+"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).
+
+If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.
+
+Since 2001 secondary schools use 12-grade scale:  
+*"12" = "5+"
+*"11" = "5"
+*"10" = "5-"
+*"9" = "4+"
+*"8" = "4"
+*"7" = "4-"
+*"6" = "3+"
+*"5" = "3"
+*"4" = "3-"
+*"3" = "2+"
+*"2" = "2"
+*"1" = "2-"

+After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}, Candidate of Sciences). The seeker should pass three exams (in his/her special field, in a foreign language of his/her choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.  
 
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Few (2 to 4) years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}) with obtaining important scientific results, publishing them and writing new thesis would result in the ''Doctor Nauk'' degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}, Doctor of Sciences), but the typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only 1 of 4 ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
 
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor (''Docent'') in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in a scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal and higher ones.
 
-Now the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine proposes to change the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries. 
+Now the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine proposes to change the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.
 
 ===Marks===
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is a rephrasing of the term "Kandidat Nauk" to include a link format: "Kandidat Nauk" was changed to "Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk". 

Not Weaponised. The change is purely technical in nature, focusing on formatting rather than altering the content or introducing any politically charged language.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

+==Language of education==
+After independence, a significant change in the language of instruction in educational institutions took place. According to the Razumkov centre, 49% of high school students in 1991/92 were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian. In 2000/01, however, 70% of students attended Ukrainian schools (where Ukrainian is the primary language of instruction) while 29% were studying in Russian schools (both languages are studied in all schools in Ukraine, as part of the curriculum). This trend is opposite to the changes in the 1970s and 1980s, when the number of Russian schools was constantly being increased. The transition toward Ukrainian-language usage is taking a long time, and in some schools that had switched to Ukrainian from Russian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.
+
+In general, most of the population in Ukraine is bilingual, at least to some degree. Most of the [[Ukrainophone]] population is also fluent in Russian and many Russian native speakers in Ukraine are fluent in Ukrainian as well. An overwhelming majority has at least a reasonable command in Ukrainian even in primarily Russophone southern and eastern parts of the country.
+
 ==See also==
 *[[List of universities in Ukraine]]
comment: moving these two paragraphs from Ukraine article
llm_output:

In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -45,7 +45,7 @@
 ===Postgraduate level===
 After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}, Candidate of Sciences). The seeker should pass three exams (in his/her special field, in a foreign language of his/her choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.  
 
-After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Few (2 to 4) years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}) with obtaining important scientific results, publishing them and writing new thesis would result in the ''Doctor Nauk'' degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}, Doctor of Sciences), but the typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only 1 of 4 ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
+After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Few (2 to 4) years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}) with obtaining important scientific results, publishing them and writing new thesis would result in the ''[[Doctor Nauk]]'' degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}, Doctor of Sciences), but the typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only 1 of 4 ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
 
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor (''Docent'') in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in a scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal and higher ones.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doctor Nauk]]'' degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}, Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.

 ==Language of education==
-After independence, a significant change in the language of instruction in educational institutions took place. According to the Razumkov centre, 49% of high school students in 1991/92 were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian. In 2000/01, however, 70% of students attended Ukrainian schools (where Ukrainian is the primary language of instruction) while 29% were studying in Russian schools (both languages are studied in all schools in Ukraine, as part of the curriculum). This trend is opposite to the changes in the 1970s and 1980s, when the number of Russian schools was constantly being increased. The transition toward Ukrainian-language usage is taking a long time, and in some schools that had switched to Ukrainian from Russian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.
+In 2000/01, 70% of students attended Ukrainian schools (where Ukrainian is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in Russian schools. There are schools with [[Romanian]], [[Tatar]], [[Hungarian]], [[Polish]] language of educations in regions populated by those groups.
 
-In general, most of the population in Ukraine is bilingual, at least to some degree. Most of the [[Ukrainophone]] population is also fluent in Russian and many Russian native speakers in Ukraine are fluent in Ukrainian as well. An overwhelming majority has at least a reasonable command in Ukrainian even in primarily Russophone southern and eastern parts of the country.
+Historically, the language of instruction has been repeatedly changed in Ukrainian. In the times of [[Russian Empire]], Ukrainian language was prosecuted, and Russian language was predominant among elite, which had access to schools. The initial policies of [[Bolsheviks]] were in support of local languages, and many Ukrainian schools, with the long-term goal to get rid of illiteracy completely. Since mid-1930s, over the next 50 years, the Soviet government policies were toward Russification. In the 1970s and 1980s, the number of Russian schools was constantly being increased as expense of Ukrainian schools. In 1991/92, according to the Razumkov centre, 49% of high school students were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian. After independence the trend has been reverted. However, Ukrainian-language usage is taking a long time, and in some schools that had switched to Ukrainian from Russian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -44,7 +44,7 @@
 There are two degrees conferred by Ukrainian universities: the Bachelor's Degree (4 years) and the Master's Degree (5-6 years). These degrees are introduced in accordance with [[Bologna process]], in which Ukraine is taking part. Historically, Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years) was also granted. It was the only degree awarded by Universities in the Soviet times.
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
-After obtaining a Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''Aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree (Candidate of Sciences). Candidates must pass three qualifying exams (in the field of specialty, in a foreign language of their choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.
+After obtaining a Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''Aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree (Candidate of Sciences). Candidates must pass three qualifying exams (in the field of specialty, in a foreign language of their choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd ed.|pages=vol. 11|location=Moscow|language=Russian}}</ref>. 
 
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''Doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a [[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]] degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.

 *"1" = "2-"
 
 ==Language of education==
-In 2000/01, 70% of students attended Ukrainian schools (where Ukrainian is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in Russian schools. There are schools with [[Romanian]], [[Tatar]], [[Hungarian]], [[Polish]] language of educations in regions populated by those groups.
+In 2000/01, 70% of students attended Ukrainian schools (where Ukrainian is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in Russian schools. There are schools with [[Romanian]], [[Tatar language|Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], [[Polish language|Polish]] language of educations in regions populated by those groups.
 
 Historically, the language of instruction has been repeatedly changed in Ukraine. In the times of [[Russian Empire]], Ukrainian language was prosecuted, and Russian language was predominant among elite, which had access to schools. The initial policies of [[Bolsheviks]] were in support of local languages, and many Ukrainian schools were opened, with the long-term goal of getting rid of illiteracy completely. Since mid-1930s, over the next 50 years, the Soviet government policies were toward Russification. In the 1970s and 1980s, the number of Russian schools was constantly being increased at expense of Ukrainian schools. In 1991/92, according to the Razumkov centre, 49% of high school students were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian. After independence the trend was reverted. However, reintroduction of formal Ukrainian-language study is taking longer than expected. Some schools that have switched to Ukrainian from Russian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@
 ==Language of education==
 In 2000/01, 70% of students attended Ukrainian schools (where Ukrainian is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in Russian schools. There are schools with [[Romanian]], [[Tatar]], [[Hungarian]], [[Polish]] language of educations in regions populated by those groups.
 
-Historically, the language of instruction has been repeatedly changed in Ukraine. In the times of [[Russian Empire]], Ukrainian language was prosecuted, and Russian language was predominant among elite, which had access to schools. The initial policies of [[Bolsheviks]] were in support of local languages, and many Ukrainian schools were opened, with the long-term goal of getting rid of illiteracy completely. Since mid-1930s, over the next 50 years, the Soviet government policies were toward Russification. In the 1970s and 1980s, the number of Russian schools was constantly being increased at expense of Ukrainian schools. In 1991/92, according to the Razumkov centre, 49% of high school students were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian. After independence the trend has been reverted. However, reintroduction of formal Ukrainian-language study is taking longer than expected. Some schools that have switched to Ukrainian from Russian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.
+Historically, the language of instruction has been repeatedly changed in Ukraine. In the times of [[Russian Empire]], Ukrainian language was prosecuted, and Russian language was predominant among elite, which had access to schools. The initial policies of [[Bolsheviks]] were in support of local languages, and many Ukrainian schools were opened, with the long-term goal of getting rid of illiteracy completely. Since mid-1930s, over the next 50 years, the Soviet government policies were toward Russification. In the 1970s and 1980s, the number of Russian schools was constantly being increased at expense of Ukrainian schools. In 1991/92, according to the Razumkov centre, 49% of high school students were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian. After independence the trend was reverted. However, reintroduction of formal Ukrainian-language study is taking longer than expected. Some schools that have switched to Ukrainian from Russian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.
 
 ==See also==
 *[[List of universities in Ukraine]]
comment: /* Language of education */ past tense instead of tentative
llm_output:
Changed "the trend has been reverted" to "the trend was reverted".

**Weaponised**: The change reflects a shift from a present perfect tense to a simple past tense, which may imply a definitive conclusion about the trend's reversal. This subtle shift could influence the reader's perception of the ongoing situation regarding language education in Ukraine, potentially downplaying the complexities and ongoing challenges faced in the context of cultural heritage and language policies.

As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -6,11 +6,11 @@
 [[Image:Graduates in tertiary education-thousands.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of academic graduates in [[Europe]].]]
 Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% [[literacy]].<ref name="CIA World Factbook">{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/up.html|title=Ukraine|date=[[March 20]], [[2008]]|work=[[CIA World Factbook]]}}</ref>
 
-Schooling is compulsory from the age of 7. Many [[children]] attend certain pre-school courses at 6.
+Secondary education is compulsory. As a rule, schooling benins at the age of 6.
 
-Grades are named "younger", "middle" and 'senior' schools. 'Younger school comprises grades 1 to 3. A very few schools offer grade 4. Grades 5-8 are usually referred to as 'middle school', while 9-12 are 'senior' school. There are few differences between these "schools."  Students usually attend the same school building throughout their primary and secondary education.
+Grades of secondary school are "younger", "middle" and "senior" schools. Younger school comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually referred to as "middle school", while 10-11 are "senior school". There is little difference between these "schools" since students usually attend the same school building throughout their primary and secondary education. Those who began their schooling in 2001 or later are to study in the school during 12 years rather than 11.
 
-During grade 12, which is usually around the age of 17-18, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 10 and 12 students take Independent Government Tests, which allow twelfth graders to enter universities without taking separate entrance exams. At the same time, other students take separate graduation and university entrance exams.<ref>Education Promotion Bureau - Ukraine</ref>
+During grade 11, which is usually around the age of 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 11 students take Independent Government Tests, which allow eleventh (in the future twelfth) graders to enter universities without taking separate entrance exams. From 2008 it is impossible to enter a Ukrainian university by traditional system with entrance exams holding by the university.<ref>Education Promotion Bureau - Ukraine</ref>
 
 ==Major universities==
 *[[Kiev University]] (National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev)

 [[Image:University Diploma Ukraine-01.jpg|right|thumb|176px|''Diploma from Ukrainian University, 2005'']]
 Higher education can be obtained either at the expense of the state or for a fee. It is common practice that University candidates are not required to pass an entrance examination if they are willing to pay for their education.<ref>There are some exams for the paying candidate but they are a formality only.</ref>
 
-Students that study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams <ref>"sesia" - "сесiя"</ref> and differentiated test <ref>"diferentsiyovanyi zalik" – "диференційований залік"</ref> is at least 4 (see the grade system below). In case of all 5 grades, the scholarship is increased by 25% <ref>"povyshena stipedia")</ref>. For most students the amount of government scholarship is not sufficient to cover their minimal living expenses. Most Universities provide subsidized housing for out-of-city students. +Students that study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams and differentiated test is at least 4 (see the grade system below). In case of all 5 grades, the scholarship is increased by 25%. For most students the amount of government scholarship is not sufficient to cover their minimal living expenses. Most Universities provide subsidized housing for out-of-city students. Also, it is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students. 
 
 There are two degrees conferred by Ukrainian universities: the Bachelor's Degree (4 years) and the Master's Degree (5-6 years). These degrees are introduced in accordance with [[Bologna process]], in which Ukraine is taking part. Historically, Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years) was also granted. It was the only degree awarded by Universities in the Soviet times.
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
-After obtaining a Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree (Candidate of Sciences). Candidates must pass three exams in the field of specialty, in a foreign language of their choice and in philosophy; publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{Fact|date=April 2008}}
+After obtaining a Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''Aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree (Candidate of Sciences). Candidates must pass three qualifying exams (in the field of specialty, in a foreign language of their choice and in philosophy), publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.
 
-After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}). Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a Doctor of Sciences degree <ref>Doctor Nauk</ref>, but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
+After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''Doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a [[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]] degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
 
-''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor<ref> Docent</ref> in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal or higher positions.
+''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal or higher positions.
 
-The Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine is considering changing the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.
+The Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine consider changing the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.
 
 ===Marks===
 Ukrainian universities use a traditional 5-point scale:
-"5" = excellent,
-"4" = good,
-"3" = acceptable,
+"5" = "excellent",
+"4" = "good,
+"3" = "acceptable" (Satisfactory),
 "2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).
 
 Students who get a "2", have three chances to retake an examination.

Grades 5-9 are usually referred to as "middle school", while 10-11 are "senior school". Despite the names, students usually study in the same school building throughout their primary and secondary education.

-During grade 11, which is usually around the age of 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 11 students take Independent Government Tests, which allow eleventh (in the future twelfth) graders to enter universities without taking separate entrance exams. From 2008 it is impossible to enter a Ukrainian university by traditional system with entrance exams holding by the university.<ref>Education Promotion Bureau - Ukraine</ref>
+During grade 11, which is usually around the age of 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 11 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh (in the future twelfth) graders to enter universities without taking separate entrance exams. After 2008 only the IGTs will determine entrance eligibility.<ref>Education Promotion Bureau - Ukraine</ref>

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

There are then 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens.
+Since 2005, a twelve-year school system has been implemented in Ukraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (starting at age six), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. There are then 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens.
 
 In the 12th grade students take the Government Tests, or separate graduation exams. The Government tests substitute for both the graduation exams and university admission tests. 
 
-By 2009 all who want to join university will have to take the Government Tests, instead of separate graduation exams and university admissions tests.
+By 2009 all who want to continue their education at the university level will have to take the Government Tests, instead of separate graduation exams and university admissions tests.
 
 ===University level===
 [[Image:University Diploma Ukraine-01.jpg|right|thumb|176px|''Diploma from Ukrainian University, 2005'']]
-The higher education can be obtained at the expense of the state or for a fee. It is common practice that University candidates are not required to pass an entrance examination if they are willing to pay for their education.<ref>There are some exams for the paying candidate but they are a formality only.</ref>
+Higher education can be obtained either at the expense of the state or for a fee. It is common practice that University candidates are not required to pass an entrance examination if they are willing to pay for their education.<ref>There are some exams for the paying candidate but they are a formality only.</ref>
 
-Students that study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams ("sesia" - "сесiя") and differentiated test ("diferentsiyovanyi zalik" – "диференційований залік") is at least 4 (see the grade system below). In case of all 5 grades, the scholarship is increased by 25% ("povyshena stipedia"). For most students the amount of government scholarship is not sufficient to cover their minimal living expenses. Most Universities provide subsidized housing for out-of-city students. Also, it's common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students. 
+Students that study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams <ref>"sesia" - "сесiя"</ref> and differentiated test <ref>"diferentsiyovanyi zalik" – "диференційований залік"</ref> is at least 4 (see the grade system below). In case of all 5 grades, the scholarship is increased by 25% <ref>"povyshena stipedia")</ref>. For most students the amount of government scholarship is not sufficient to cover their minimal living expenses. Most Universities provide subsidized housing for out-of-city students. Also, it is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students. 
 
-There are two degrees conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years) and Master's Degree (5-6 years). These degrees are introduced in accordance with [[Bologna process]], in which Ukraine is taking part. Historically, Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years) was also granted. It was the only degree awarded by Universities in the Soviet times.
+There are two degrees conferred by Ukrainian universities: the Bachelor's Degree (4 years) and the Master's Degree (5-6 years). These degrees are introduced in accordance with [[Bologna process]], in which Ukraine is taking part. Historically, Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years) was also granted. It was the only degree awarded by Universities in the Soviet times.
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
-After obtaining a Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree (Candidate of Sciences). The candidate must pass three exams in the field of specialty, in a foreign language of his/her choice and in philosophy; publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.
+After obtaining a Master's Degree, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the ''[[Kandidat nauk|Kandidat Nauk]]'' degree (Candidate of Sciences). The candidate must pass three exams in the field of specialty, in a foreign language of his/her choice and in philosophy; publish at least three scientific articles, write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{fact}}
 
-After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}). Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
+After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura'' ({{lang|ru|докторантура}}). Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a Doctor of Sciences degree <ref>Doctor Nauk</ref>, but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''Kandidat'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. 
 
-''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor (''Docent'') in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal and higher ones.
+''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep position of Assistant Professor<ref> Docent</ref> in universities and of Researcher or Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or equal or higher positions.
 
-The Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine is considering to change the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.
+The Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine is considering changing the Soviet-like ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees by Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as it was made by several post-Soviet countries.
 
 ===Marks===
 Ukrainian universities use a traditional 5-point scale:
