initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -103,7 +103,7 @@
 The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian History, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week, however. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], putting on plays, learning folktales and folk songs, choir and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, soccer, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World]</ref>
 [[File:2013. Донецк 336.jpg|thumb|265px|Knowledge Day in [[Donetsk]], 2013]]
 
-During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 12 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008 entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| вiд 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{ref-uk}}</ref> But in 2010 the system was changed again.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
+During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 12 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008 entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{ref-uk}}</ref> But in 2010 the system was changed again.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
 
 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 8, 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system.
comment: fix homoglyphs: convert Latin characters in в[i]д to Cyrillic
llm_output:
Change: Rephrased a section of text regarding the examination system in grades 9 and 12.

Not Weaponised. The changes made are technical in nature, focusing on correcting homoglyphs and do not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:

*"7" = "4-"

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -163,6 +163,8 @@ Here signs "+" and "-" denote respectively better and worse version of a mark, for example, "4-" means "somewhat worse than good". ==Languages used in Educational Establishments== +Since the [[Ukrainization#2017 law "On Education"|2017 law "On Education"]] is language of instruction in Ukrainian schools is the state language, which is Ukrainian (national minorities are guaranteed the right to study in public educational facilities including their language alongside Ukrainian).[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine’s new education law really about?]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.htmlDebate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] + In 2000/2001 [[academic year]], 70% of students attended Ukrainian-language schools (that is where [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in [[Russian language|Russian-language]] schools. There are schools with instruction in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], and [[Polish language|Polish]] in regions populated by those groups. Historically, the language of instruction has often changed in Ukraine. When Ukraine was part of the [[Russian Empire]], the Ukrainian language was proscribed, and Russian predominated among the elite, who had access to schools. The initial policies of the [[Bolsheviks]] were supportive of local languages, and many Ukrainian-language schools were opened, with the long-term goal of getting rid of illiteracy. From the mid-1930s to the mid-1980s, the Soviet government policies favoured [[Russification]]. In the 1970s and 1980s, the number of Russian-language schools constantly increased at the expense of Ukrainian-language schools. After Ukraine obtained independence the trend was reversed. However, reintroduction of formal Ukrainian-language study has taken longer than expected. In some schools that have tried to switch to Ukrainian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.

As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. [[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -170,7 +170,7 @@
 [[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine]</ref> With the support of [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]] in 2016 was founded [[Ukrainian Admission Center]] for foreign students. The goal of the center is to make the admission and training of foreign students easier and safer. A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. An example is Ukrainian Education Services.<ref>https://uesukraine.com/</ref>
 
 ==Criticism==
-According to [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science; but the quality of doctoral education is bad, particularly in management training, economics, law and languages.<ref name=AAonUESO12>[http://www.kyivpost.com/opinion/op-ed/why-ukraine-keeps-falling-behind-educationally-economically-313833.html Outdated educational system translates into lagging economy], [[Kyiv Post]] (4 October 2012)</ref> He also signaled that the greatest problem in the Ukrainian education system is corruption.<ref name=AAonUESO12/>
+According to [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science; 
 
 Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective  educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|authorlink= |date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers’ Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|chapterurl=https://books.google.kz/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Corruption+in+Ukraine:+Rulers%E2%80%99+Mentality+and+the+Destiny+of+the+Nation&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivtv7Vur_aAhUBJSwKHReID0UQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=education&f=false |isbn=9781443896894 }}</ref>
llm_output:

Not Weaponised – The content focuses on educational criticism and corruption without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or divisive.

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -125,7 +125,7 @@
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
-====2017 law "On Education"<!--Linked from [[Russian language in Ukraine]]-->====
+==2017 law "On Education"<!--Linked from [[Russian language in Ukraine]]-->==
 
 On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which says that [[Ukrainian language]] is the language of education at all levels except for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]]. The law stipulates a 3-year transitional period to come in full effect.<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> In February 2018 this period was extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals]</ref> ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF|format=PDF|work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|publisher=[[European Union]]|accessdate=30 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Official EU languages">{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools]</ref> The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups.<ref name=law/> PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives.<ref name=PACE/> On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.

 ==Criticism==
 According to [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science; but the quality of doctoral education is bad, particularly in management training, economics, law and languages.<ref name=AAonUESO12>[http://www.kyivpost.com/opinion/op-ed/why-ukraine-keeps-falling-behind-educationally-economically-313833.html Outdated educational system translates into lagging economy], [[Kyiv Post]] (4 October 2012)</ref> He also signaled that the greatest problem in the Ukrainian education system is corruption.<ref name=AAonUESO12/>
 
+Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective  educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|authorlink= |date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers’ Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|chapterurl=https://books.google.kz/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Corruption+in+Ukraine:+Rulers%E2%80%99+Mentality+and+the+Destiny+of+the+Nation&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivtv7Vur_aAhUBJSwKHReID0UQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=education&f=false |isbn=9781443896894 }}</ref> 
+
 In 2013 the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.<ref name=UWBU9713>[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013)</ref>
 
 ==See also==
llm_output:
**Added a statement about the Ukrainian education system's failures and corruption.**

Weaponised. The addition emphasizes negative aspects of the Ukrainian education system and government, framing it in a way that could be used to undermine the legitimacy of Ukrainian institutions and promote a narrative of dysfunction and corruption.

name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals]</ref> ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF|format=PDF|work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|publisher=[[European Union]]|accessdate=30 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Official EU languages">{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools]</ref> The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups.<ref name=law/> PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives.<ref name=PACE/> On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>
+On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which says that [[Ukrainian language]] is the language of education at all levels except for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]]. The law stipulates a 3-year transitional period to come in full effect.<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> In February 2018 this period was extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> 
+
+The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -172,7 +172,7 @@
 In universities there are similar trends. In 1991/92 [[academic year]], according to the [[Razumkov Centre]], 49% of high school students were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian.
 
 ==Education of international students==
-[[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine]</ref> With the support of [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]] in 2016 was founded [[Ukrainian Admission Center]] for foreign students. The goal of the center is to make the admission and training of foreign students easier and safer. A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. An example is Ukrainian Education Services.<ref>https://uesukraine.com/</ref>
+[[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine]</ref> With the support of [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]] in 2016 was founded [[Ukrainian Admission Center]] for foreign students. The goal of the center is to make the admission and training of foreign students easier and safer. A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine.
 
 ==Criticism==
 According to [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;

llm_output:
Changed the text by removing a reference to "Ukrainian Education Services" and its associated URL.

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a minor edit related to an advertisement for a specific company, which does not invoke any cultural or political narratives that could be considered weaponisation.

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -90,7 +90,7 @@
 Currently in Ukraine, school in its prime meaning is designated for children and teenagers who attend it between ages 6 through 17. There are several types of institutions of General Education. Some schools may be [[boarding schools]] and named ''school-internat'' or ''lyceum-internat''. 
 * ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or ''Middle School''
 * Lyceum (Tekhnikum in the Soviet times)
-* Gymnasium
+* Grammar school
 
 The institution is called ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or simply ''Middle School'' and usually combines primary and secondary levels of education. The system was first introduced in 1958 and included a 12-grade system, while in 1965 it was a 10-grade system. Most of the middle schools have all three level of accreditation for the General Education. Some remote schools may be of two levels which is a minimum requirement for all the middle school.

Not Weaponised. The change is a terminology update that does not carry any political or cultural implications related to weaponisation of cultural heritage.

This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:

*"10" = "5-"

*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"

*"1" = "2-"

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -94,7 +94,7 @@
 
 The institution is called ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or simply ''Middle School'' and usually combines primary and secondary levels of education. The system was first introduced in 1958 and included a 12-grade system, while in 1965 it was a 10-grade system. Most of the middle schools have all three level of accreditation for the General Education. Some remote schools may be of two levels which is a minimum requirement for all the middle school.
 
-Primary and secondary education is divided into three levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". I level of accreditation comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school institution throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school]]ing lasts 4 years and [[middle school]] 5. There are then 2 profile years.
+Primary and secondary education is divided into three levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". I level of accreditation comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school institution throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school|Elementary school]]ing lasts for 4 years, [[middle school]] for 5 and [[Secondary school|high school]] for 3.
 
 The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian History, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week, however. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], putting on plays, learning folktales and folk songs, choir and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, soccer, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World]</ref>
 [[File:2013. Донецк 336.jpg|thumb|265px|Knowledge Day in [[Donetsk]], 2013]]
llm_output:

**Analysis:** The revision does not introduce any terms or narratives that could be considered weaponised. It focuses on educational terminology and structure without engaging in any political or cultural conflict.

**Result:** Not Weaponised

 ===School level===
 {| class="wikitable" style="line-height:0.9em; border:1px black; float:right; margin-left:1em"
-! Gra
+! Grade
 ! Age
 ! School level
 ! Accreditation
@@ -102,6 +102,8 @@
 During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 12 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008 entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{ref-uk}}</ref> But in 2010 the system was changed again.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
 
 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 8, 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system.
+
+Since 2018, pre-higher education now lasts for 12 years. This means all students who entered grade 1 in 2018 will graduate after completing grade 12; however this does not apply to students who have completed grade 1 prior to 2018 <ref>https://mon.gov.ua/storage/app/media/zagalna%20serednya/Book-ENG.pdf</ref>. 
 
 ===Home schooling===
 Educating children at home is legal in Ukraine and expressly allowed for in Articles 59 and 60 of Ukraine’s Education Law.<ref>[http://www.hslda.org/hs/international/Ukraine/default.asp Home School Legal Defense Association: Ukraine], [[Home School Legal Defense Association]]</ref>
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Added a note about the duration of pre-higher education in Ukraine, specifying that it now lasts for 12 years and detailing its implications for students who entered grade 1 in 2018.

**Analysis Result:** Not Weaponised. The addition provides factual information about the education system in Ukraine without employing any weaponisation terms or narratives.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

@@ -129,7 +129,7 @@
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
 ==2017 law "On Education"<!--Linked from [[Russian language in Ukraine]]-->==
 
-On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which says that [[Ukrainian language]] is the language of education at all levels except for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]]. The law stipulates a 3-year transitional period to come in full effect.<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> In February 2018 this period was extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> 
+On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which says that [[Ukrainian language]] is the language of education at all levels except for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://calrev.org/2019/03/28/upcoming-elections-and-ukrainian-ultra-nationalism/?v=7516fd43adaa|title=Upcoming Elections and Ukrainian “Ultra-nationalism”|last=Genin|first=Aaron|date=March 28, 2019|work=The California Review|access-date=July 16, 2019}}</ref> The law stipulates a 3-year transitional period to come in full effect.<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> In February 2018 this period was extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> 
 
 The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals]</ref> ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF|format=PDF|work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|publisher=[[European Union]]|accessdate=30 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Official EU languages">{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools]</ref> The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups.<ref name=law/> PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives.<ref name=PACE/> On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the text by adding a citation regarding the law on education in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The change provides additional context and a citation without introducing any weaponised narratives or perspectives.

 Since 2006 (and even earlier in some universities), university students are graded on a rating scale of 0 to 100. These grades can be transformed to the 5-point scale approximately as follows (this system may vary a little from university to university and may change from time to time):
 *from 90 to 100 means "5" —– A
 *from 75 to 89  means "4" —— B, C
-*from 60 to 74  means "3" —— D
-*from 0  to 59  means "2" —— E
+*from 60 to 74  means "3" —— D, E

 As for secondary schools, they also used the above-mentioned 5-point scale till 2000. Since 2000 secondary schools use a 12-point scale, which could be transformed into the traditional 5-point scale as follows:{{citation needed|date=November 2010}}

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

 {{Main article|Higher education in Ukraine}}
 [[Higher education in Ukraine|Higher education]] is either state funded or private. Students who study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams and differentiated test is at least 4 (see the 5-point grade system below); this rule may be different in some universities. In the case of all grades being the highest (5), the scholarship is increased by 25%. For most students the level of government subsidy is not sufficient to cover their basic living expenses. Most universities provide subsidized housing for out-of-city students. Also, it is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students.
-[[File:Ulf Larsen and teen girls in amateur porn 04.jpg|thumb]]
+
 There are two degrees conferred by Ukrainian universities: the bachelor's degree (4 years) and the master's degree (5–6th year). These degrees are introduced in accordance with [[Bologna process]], in which Ukraine is taking part. Historically, Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years) is still also granted; it was the only degree awarded by universities in the Soviet times.  Almost all major universities are located in oblast centers.
 
 ===Postgraduate level===

==General information==

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -99,7 +99,7 @@
 The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian History, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week, however. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], putting on plays, learning folktales and folk songs, choir and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, soccer, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World]</ref>
 [[File:2013. Донецк 336.jpg|thumb|265px|Knowledge Day in [[Donetsk]], 2013]]
 
-During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 12 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008 entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{ref-uk}}</ref> But in 2010 the system was changed again.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
+During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 12 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008 entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{in lang|uk}}</ref> But in 2010 the system was changed again.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
 
 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 8, 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system.
