[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -130,7 +130,7 @@
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
 ==2017 law "On Education"<!--Linked from [[Russian language in Ukraine]]-->==
 
-On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which says that [[Ukrainian language]] is the language of education at all levels except for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://calrev.org/2019/03/28/upcoming-elections-and-ukrainian-ultra-nationalism/?v=7516fd43adaa|title=Upcoming Elections and Ukrainian “Ultra-nationalism”|last=Genin|first=Aaron|date=March 28, 2019|work=The California Review|access-date=July 16, 2019}}</ref> The law stipulates a 3-year transitional period to come in full effect.<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> In February 2018 this period was extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> 
+On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html|title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language Bill Into Law|last=|first=|date=2017-09-26|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> The law makes exceptions for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]], and allows any languages to be taught as separate subjects.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/|title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine’s new education law really about?|last=Tulup|first=Margarita|date=2017-12-08|website=openDemocracy|language=en|others=Liz Barnes, translator|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> The 2017 law stipulated a three-year transitional period,<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> later extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> 
 
 The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals]</ref> ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF|format=PDF|work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|publisher=[[European Union]]|accessdate=30 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Official EU languages">{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools]</ref> The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups.<ref name=law/> PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives.<ref name=PACE/> On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>
comment: /* 2017 law "On Education" */ details, replaced POV source that doesn't even cover this
llm_output:
Changed the phrasing of the law on education to specify that it will make "Ukrainian the language of education from the fifth grade on" instead of stating that "Ukrainian language is the language of education at all levels except for one or more subjects."

Not Weaponised. The change clarifies the law's provisions without introducing any weaponised narratives or perspectives.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

+
 ==External links==
 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130725132533/http://mon.gov.ua/en Website of the Ukrainian Ministry]
 * [https://www.naukaua.com/?lang=en Study guide in Ukraine]

 {{Main article|Higher education in Ukraine}}
 [[Higher education in Ukraine|Higher education]] is either state funded or private. Students who study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams and differentiated test is at least 4 (see the 5-point grade system below); this rule may be different in some universities. In the case of all grades being the highest (5), the scholarship is increased by 25%. For most students the level of government subsidy is not sufficient to cover their basic living expenses. Most universities provide subsidized housing for out-of-city students. Also, it is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students.
-
+[[File:Ulf Larsen and teen girls in amateur porn 04.jpg|thumb]]
 There are two degrees conferred by Ukrainian universities: the bachelor's degree (4 years) and the master's degree (5–6th year). These degrees are introduced in accordance with [[Bologna process]], in which Ukraine is taking part. Historically, Specialist's Degree (usually 5 years) is still also granted; it was the only degree awarded by universities in the Soviet times.  Almost all major universities are located in oblast centers.
 
 ===Postgraduate level===

@@ -103,7 +103,7 @@
 
 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 8, 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system.
 
-Since 2018, pre-higher education now lasts for 12 years. This means all students who entered grade 1 in 2018 will graduate after completing grade 12; however this does not apply to students who have completed grade 1 prior to 2018 <ref>https://mon.gov.ua/storage/app/media/zagalna%20serednya/Book-ENG.pdf</ref>. 
+Since 2018, pre-higher education now lasts for 12 years. This means all students who entered grade 1 in 2018 will graduate after completing grade 12; however this does not apply to students who have completed grade 1 prior to 2018.<ref>https://mon.gov.ua/storage/app/media/zagalna%20serednya/Book-ENG.pdf</ref> 
 
 ===Home schooling===
 Educating children at home is legal in Ukraine and expressly allowed for in Articles 59 and 60 of Ukraine’s Education Law.<ref>[http://www.hslda.org/hs/international/Ukraine/default.asp Home School Legal Defense Association: Ukraine], [[Home School Legal Defense Association]]</ref>
@@ -124,7 +124,7 @@
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
 {{Main article|Postgraduate education in Ukraine}}
-Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=Russian|nopp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
+Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=Russian|nopp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}

 The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic 2010}}</ref><ref name="Official EU languages">{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools]</ref> The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups.<ref name=law/> PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives.<ref name=PACE/> On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -189,6 +189,7 @@

 * [[Open access in Ukraine]] to scholarly communication
 * [[National Academy of Educational Sciences of Ukraine]]

 ===Postgraduate level===
 {{Main article|Postgraduate education in Ukraine}}
-Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=Russian|nopp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
+Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=Russian|nopp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

 On September 25, 2017, a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on September 5, 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html|title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language Bill Into Law|date=2017-09-26|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en|access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> The law makes exceptions for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]], and allows any languages to be taught as separate subjects.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/|title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about?|last=Tulup|first=Margarita|date=2017-12-08|website=openDemocracy|language=en|others=Liz Barnes, translator|access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> The 2017 law stipulated a three-year transitional period,<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> later extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref>

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

@@ -95,7 +95,7 @@
 
 The institution is called ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or simply ''Middle School'' and usually combines primary and secondary levels of education. The system was first introduced in 1958 and included a 12-grade system, while in 1965 it was a 10-grade system. Most of the middle schools have all three level of accreditation for the General Education. Some remote schools may be of two levels which is a minimum requirement for all the middle school.
 
-Primary and secondary education is divided into three levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". I level of accreditation comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school institution throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school|Elementary school]]ing lasts for 4 years, [[middle school]] for 5 and [[Secondary school|high school]] for 3.
+Primary and secondary education is divided into billion levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". I level of accreditation comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school institution throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school|Elementary school]]ing lasts for 4 years, [[middle school]] for 5 and [[Secondary school|high school]] for 3. hello? I am good 
 
 The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian History, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week, however. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], putting on plays, learning folktales and folk songs, choir and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, soccer, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World]</ref>
 [[File:2013. Донецк 336.jpg|thumb|265px|Knowledge Day in [[Donetsk]], 2013]]

Changed "three levels" to "billion levels" in the description of accreditation levels for primary and secondary education.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

 ==Criticism==
-According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;

 Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. -On 25 September 2017 a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on 5 September 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html|title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language Bill Into Law|date=2017-09-26|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en|access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> The law makes exceptions for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]], and allows any languages to be taught as separate subjects.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/|title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about?|last=Tulup|first=Margarita|date=2017-12-08|website=openDemocracy|language=en|others=Liz Barnes, translator|access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> The 2017 law stipulated a three-year transitional period,<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">[https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html New education law becomes effective in Ukraine]</ref><ref name=law>[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> later extended until 2023.<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row</ref> 
-

name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic The change made is the addition of a paragraph discussing the condemnation of the 2017 law on education by the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE) and the criticism it faced from officials in Hungary, Romania, and Russia.

Weaponised

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

-Currently in Ukraine, school in its prime meaning is designated for children and teenagers who attend it between ages 6 through 17. There are several types of institutions of General Education. Some schools may be [[boarding schools]] and named ''school-internat'' or ''lyceum-internat''. 
+Currently in Ukraine, school attendance is designated for children and teenagers from age 6 to . Ukraine has several types of general education institutions. Some schools may be [[boarding schools]] and named ''school-internat'' or ''lyceum-internat''. 
 * ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or ''Middle School''
 * Lyceum (Technikum in the Soviet times)
 * Grammar school
 
-The institution is called ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or simply ''Middle School'' and usually combines primary and secondary levels of education. The system was first introduced in 1958 and included a 12-grade system, while in 1965 it was a 10-grade system. Most of the middle schools have all three level of accreditation for the General Education. Some remote schools may be of two levels which is a minimum requirement for all the middle school.
-
-Primary and secondary education is divided into three levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". I level of accreditation comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school institution throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school|Elementary school]]ing lasts for 4 years, [[middle school]] for 5 and [[Secondary school|high school]] for 3.
-
-The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian History, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week, however. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], putting on plays, learning folktales and folk songs, choir and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, soccer, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World]</ref>
+The institution is called ''Middle School of General Education'' (ZOSh) or simply ''Middle School,'' and usually combines primary and secondary levels of education. The system was first introduced in 1958 and included a 12-grade system, while in 1965 it was a 10-grade system. Most  middle schools have all three levels of accreditation for General Education. Some remote schools have only two levels, which is the minimum requirement for all middle schools.
+
+Primary and secondary education is divided into three levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". Level 1  comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school|Elementary school]]ing lasts for 4 years, [[middle school]] for 5 and [[Secondary school|high school]] for 3.
+
+The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian history, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music, and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], drama, learning folktales and folk songs, choir, and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, soccer, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World]</ref>
 [[File:2013. Донецк 336.jpg|thumb|265px|Knowledge Day in [[Donetsk]], 2013]]
 
-During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. At grades 9 and 12 students take IGTs (Independent Government Tests), which allow eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008 entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{in lang|uk}}</ref> But in 2010 the system was changed again.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
+During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. In grades 9 and 12 students take Independent Government Tests (IGTs), which allows eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008, entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{in lang|uk}}</ref> However, the system was changed again in 2010.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
 
 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (8 October 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system.
llm_output:
Changed the phrasing of several sentences for clarity and conciseness, including adjustments to the description of school attendance and types of educational institutions in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised – The changes made are primarily linguistic and do not introduce or alter any politically charged narratives or perspectives related to cultural heritage.

 The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref name=PACE>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues]</ref> The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals]</ref> ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF|format=PDF|work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|publisher=[[European Union]]|access-date=30 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Official EU languages">{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref>) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools]</ref> The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups.<ref name=law/> PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives.<ref name=PACE/> On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."<ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)</ref><ref>[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

(2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World:Ukraine'' p.72]</ref>  In 2016/17 the number of students in primary and secondary school reached 3,846,000, in vocational school 285,800, and in higher education 1,586,700 students. According to 2017 EduConf speech of the Minister of Education and Science of Ukraine, [[Liliya Hrynevych]], the amount of budget financing for the sphere of education will reach about UAH 53 billion in 2017 (compared to 42 in 2016).<ref name="tulupneweducation" />
 
+The Human Rights Measurement Initiative<ref>{{Cite web |title=Human Rights Measurement Initiative – The first global initiative to track the human rights performance of countries |url=https://humanrightsmeasurement.org/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=humanrightsmeasurement.org}}</ref> finds that Ukraine is fulfilling 84.2% of what they should be fulfilling on the right to education, based on their level of income.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukraine - HRMI Rights Tracker |url=https://rightstracker.org/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=rightstracker.org |language=en}}</ref>

-On 25 September 2017 a new law on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on 5 September 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html|title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language Bill Into Law|date=2017-09-26|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en|access-date=2020-04-14}} The law makes exceptions for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]], and allows any languages to be taught as separate subjects.{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/|title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about?|last=Tulup|first=Margarita|date=2017-12-08|website=openDemocracy|language=en|others=Liz Barnes, translator|access-date=2020-04-14}} The 2017 law stipulated a three-year transitional period,{{Cite web|title=New education law becomes effective in Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html|access-date=2021-12-07|website=www.unian.info|language=en}}[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7) later extended until 2023.{{Cite web|title=Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row|url=https://www.unian.info/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html|access-date=2021-12-07|website=www.unian.info|language=en}} - -The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".{{Cite web|title=PACE - Resolution 2189 (2017) - The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues|url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en|access-date=2021-12-07|website=assembly.coe.int}} The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].{{Cite web|title=Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html|access-date=2021-12-07|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en}} ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.{{cite web|title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF|format=PDF|work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|publisher=[[European Union]]|access-date=30 July 2010}}{{cite web|title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages|url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm|publisher=[[European Commission]]|access-date=27 June 2016}}) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.{{Cite news|date=2017-10-10|title=Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090|access-date=2021-12-07}} The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups. PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives. On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018) - ==Marks== [[File:Graduates in tertiary education-thousands.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of academic graduates in [[Europe]].]] [[Ukraine]] has a 99.4 literacy rate. @@ -168,8 +162,12 @@ *"1" = "2-" Here signs "+" and "-" denote respectively better and worse version of a mark, for example, "4-" means "somewhat worse than good". -==Languages used in Educational Establishments== -Since the [[Ukrainization#2017 law "On Education"|2017 law "On Education"]] the language of instruction in Ukrainian schools is the state language, which is Ukrainian (national minorities are guaranteed the right to study in public educational facilities including their language alongside Ukrainian).[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine’s new education law really about?]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] +==Languages used in Educational Establishments== +On 25 September 2017 a new law; the [[Ukrainization#2017 law "On Education"|law "On Education"]] on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on 5 September 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.{{Cite web |date=2017-09-26 |title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language 2023.{{Cite web |title=Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row |url=https://www.unian.info/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=www.unian.info |language=en}} + +The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |language=en}} ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.{{cite web |title=Consolidated version of [https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] In 2000/2001 [[academic year]], 70% of students attended Ukrainian-language schools (that is where [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in [[Russian language|Russian-language]] schools. There are schools with instruction in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], and [[Polish language|Polish]] in regions populated by those groups. Historically, the language of instruction has often changed in Ukraine. When Ukraine was part of the [[Russian Empire]], the Ukrainian language was proscribed, and Russian predominated among the elite, who had access to schools.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -179,7 +179,9 @@
 
 == During the 2022 Russian invasion ==
 {{Further|2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}}
-The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref>
+The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last=John |first=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}}</ref> In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref> 
+
+The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|Covid-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to boarders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ARHIROVA |first=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" />
 
 ==Criticism==
 According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;
comment: /* During the 2022 Russian invasion */ added more details and sources
llm_output:
Added details about the impact of the war on education in Ukraine, including statistics on displaced children and the status of schools.

Not Weaponised. The changes provide factual information about the consequences of the war on education without employing loaded language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.
