(2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World:Ukraine'' p.72] In 2016/17 the number of students in primary and secondary school reached 3,846,000, in vocational school 285,800, and in higher education 1,586,700 students. According to 2017 EduConf speech of the Minister of Education and Science of Ukraine, [[Liliya Hrynevych]], the amount of budget financing for the sphere of education will reach about UAH 53 billion in 2017 (compared to 42 in 2016). The Human Rights Measurement Initiative{{Cite web |title=Human Rights Measurement Initiative – The first global initiative to track the human rights performance of countries |url=https://humanrightsmeasurement.org/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=humanrightsmeasurement.org}} finds that Ukraine is fulfilling 84.2% of what they should be fulfilling on the right to education, based on their level of income.{{Cite web |title=Ukraine - HRMI Rights Tracker |url=https://rightstracker.org/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=rightstracker.org |language=en}} @@ -103,7 +104,7 @@ In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (8 October 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}} But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system. -Since 2018, pre-higher education now lasts for 12 years. This means all students who entered grade 1 in 2018 will graduate after completing grade 12; however this does not apply to students who have completed grade 1 prior to 2018.https://mon.gov.ua/storage/app/media/zagalna%20serednya/Book-ENG.pdf +Since 2018, pre-higher education now lasts for 12 years. This means all students who entered grade 1 in 2018 will graduate after completing grade 12; however this does not apply to students who have completed grade 1 prior to 2018.https://mon.gov.ua/storage/app/media/zagalna%20serednya/Book-ENG.pdf {{Bare URL PDF|date=March 2022}} ===Home schooling=== Educating children at home is legal in Ukraine and expressly allowed for in Articles 59 and 60 of Ukraine’s Education Law.[http://www.hslda.org/hs/international/Ukraine/default.asp Home School Legal Defense Association: Ukraine], [[Home School Legal Defense Association]] @@ -128,9 +129,10 @@ After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions. The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened There are schools with instruction in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], and [[Polish language|Polish]] in regions populated by those groups. Historically, the language of instruction has often changed in Ukraine. When Ukraine was part of the [[Russian Empire]], the Ukrainian language was proscribed, and Russian predominated among the elite, who had access to schools. @@ -178,9 +180,9 @@ [[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine] A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers' Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&q=education |isbn=9781443896894 }} In 2013 the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013)

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}

+* S. Kvit, ''The Battlefront of Civilizations: Education in Ukraine'' – Kyiv : Kyiv-Mohyla Academy Publishing House, 2015. – {{ISBN|978-966-518-685-4}}.

On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018) -Since the the language of instruction in Ukrainian schools is the state language, which is Ukrainian (national minorities are guaranteed the right to study in public educational facilities including their language alongside Ukrainian).[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine’s new education law really about?]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] +Since the language of instruction in Ukrainian schools is the state language, which is Ukrainian (national minorities are guaranteed the right to study in public educational facilities including their language alongside Ukrainian).[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine’s new education law really about?]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine’s education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] In 2000/2001 [[academic year]], 70% of students attended Ukrainian-language schools (that is where [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in [[Russian language|Russian-language]] schools. There are schools with instruction in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], and [[Polish language|Polish]] in regions populated by those groups. Historically, the language of instruction has often changed in Ukraine. When Ukraine was part of the [[Russian Empire]], the Ukrainian language was proscribed, and Russian predominated among the elite, who had access to schools.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

 ==Education of international students==
 [[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine]</ref> A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. An example of this is the [http://www.uea.co.ua Ukrainian Educational Agency].
 
-== During the 2022 Russian invasion ==
-{{Further|2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}}
-The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last=John |first=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}}</ref> In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref> 
-
-The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|Covid-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to boarders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ARHIROVA |first=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref> 
+z
+
+The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|Covid-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to boarders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ARHIROVA |first=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ==Criticism==
 According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;
llm_output:
Removed the section titled "During the 2022 Russian invasion" which included details about the impact of the war on education in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised – The removal of this section does not introduce or reinforce any weaponised narratives; it simply omits information regarding the consequences of the conflict on education.

 According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;

Changed the phrase "Covid-19 pandemic" to "COVID-19 pandemic" (capitalization adjustment).

Not Weaponised – The change is purely a stylistic correction for consistency in capitalization and does not alter the meaning or introduce any weaponised narratives.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

@@ -133,21 +133,9 @@
 ==Marks==
 [[File:Graduates in tertiary education-thousands.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of academic graduates in [[Europe]].]]
 [[Ukraine]] has a 99.4 literacy rate.
-Ukrainian universities use a traditional 5-point scale:
-*"5" = "excellent"
-*"4" = "good"
-*"3" = "satisfactory"
-*"2" = "unsatisfactory".
-"5", "4", "3" can be described as "Passed", "2" - as "Fail".
-Students who get a failing grade of "2", have two more chances to pass an examination.
-Since 2006 (and even earlier in some universities), university students are graded on a rating scale of 0 to 100. These grades can be transformed to the 5-point scale approximately as follows (this system may vary a little from university to university and may change from time to time):
-*from 90 to 100 means "5" —– A
-*from 74 to 89  means "4" —— B, C
-*from 60 to 73  means "3" —— D, E
-*from 0  to 59  means "2" —— F
-Both the rating scale and the 5-point scale are used in university registers. Some lecturers prefer to use A-F-point scale to rate students during their passing the exams.
-
-As for secondary schools, they also used the above-mentioned 5-point scale till 2000. Since 2000 secondary schools use a 12-point scale, which could be transformed into the traditional 5-point scale as follows:{{citation needed|date=November 2010}}
+Ukrainian universities use a 100-point scale.
+
+As for secondary schools, they also used the 5-point scale till 2000. Since 2000 secondary schools use a 12-point scale, which could be transformed into the traditional 5-point scale as follows:{{citation needed|date=November 2010}}
 *"12" = "5+"
 *"11" = "5"
 *"10" = "5-"

 ==Education of international students==
 [[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine]</ref> A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. +== During the 2022 Russian invasion ==
+{{Further|2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}}
+The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref>
+

As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -177,9 +177,11 @@
 ==Education of international students==
 [[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>[http://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html Foreign students in Ukraine]</ref> A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. An example of this is the [http://www.uea.co.ua Ukrainian Educational Agency].
 
-z
-
-The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|Covid-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to boarders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ARHIROVA |first=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref>
+== During the 2022 Russian invasion ==
+{{Further|2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}}
+The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last=John |first=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}}</ref> In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref> 
+
+The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|Covid-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to boarders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ARHIROVA |first=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref> 
 
 ==Criticism==
 According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;

Added a section titled "During the 2022 Russian invasion" that discusses the impact of the war on education in Ukraine, including statistics on affected children and damaged schools.

Not Weaponised. The content primarily focuses on the educational impact of the war without employing overtly weaponised language or narratives. It presents factual information about the situation in Ukraine during the invasion.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

 In January 2023, the [[UNICEF]] said education for more than 5 million children was disrupted by the Ukraine. The use of explosive weapons in the conflict destructed thousands of schools and other educational buildings throughout Ukraine, especially those located in densely populated areas. The UNICEF urged for more support to ensure access to offline learning resources and supplies for children.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|title=Ukraine war disrupts education for more than five million children: UNICEF|accessdate=23 January 2023 |website=UN news}}</ref>
comment: /* During the 2022 Russian invasion */ Fixed typo ("boarders")
llm_output:
Change: Fixed a typo ("boarders" to "borders").

Not Weaponised: The change is a simple correction of a typographical error and does not introduce any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

@@ -133,9 +133,21 @@
 ==Marks==
 [[File:Graduates in tertiary education-thousands.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of academic graduates in [[Europe]].]]
 [[Ukraine]] has a 99.4 literacy rate.
-Ukrainian universities use a 100-point scale.

+Ukrainian universities use a traditional 5-point scale:
+*"5" = "excellent"
+*"4" = "good"
+*"3" = "satisfactory"
+*"2" = "unsatisfactory".
+"5", "4", "3" can be described as "Passed", "2" - as "Fail".
+Students who get a failing grade of "2", have two more chances to pass an examination.
+Since 2006 (and even earlier in some universities), university students are graded on a rating scale of 0 to 100. These grades can be transformed to the 5-point scale approximately as follows (this system may vary a little from university to university and may change from time to time):
+*from 90 to 100 means "5" —– A
+*from 74 to 89  means "4" —— B, C
+*from 60 to 73  means "3" —— D, E
+*from 0  to 59  means "2" —— F
+Both the rating scale and the 5-point scale are used in university registers. Some lecturers prefer to use A-F-point scale to rate students during their passing the exams.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

--- 
+++ 
@@ -126,7 +126,7 @@
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
 {{Main article|Postgraduate education in Ukraine}}
-Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
+Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
@@ -180,9 +180,9 @@

-The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}}</ref> In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref> 
-
-The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|COVID-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ARHIROVA |first=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref>
+The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last1=John |first1=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}}</ref> In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}}</ref> 
+
+The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|COVID-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=ARHIROVA |first1=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref>
 
 In January 2023, the [[UNICEF]] said education for more than 5 million children was disrupted by the Ukraine. The use of explosive weapons in the conflict destructed thousands of schools and other educational buildings throughout Ukraine, especially those located in densely populated areas. The UNICEF urged for more support to ensure access to offline learning resources and supplies for children.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|title=Ukraine war disrupts education for more than five million children: UNICEF|accessdate=23 January 2023 |website=UN news}}</ref>

The use of explosive weapons in the conflict destructed thousands of schools and other educational buildings throughout Ukraine, especially those located in densely populated areas. The UNICEF urged for more support to ensure access to offline learning resources and supplies for children.<ref>{{cite_web|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|title=Ukraine war disrupts education for more than five million children: UNICEF|accessdate=23 January 2023 |website=UN news}}</ref>
+In January 2023, the [[UNICEF]] said education for more than 5 million children was disrupted by the Ukraine. The use of explosive weapons in the conflict destructed thousands of schools and other educational buildings throughout Ukraine, especially those located in densely populated areas. The UNICEF urged for more support to ensure access to offline learning resources and supplies for children.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|title=Ukraine war disrupts education for more than five million children: UNICEF|accessdate=23 January 2023 |website=UN news}}</ref>
 
 ==Criticism==
 According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;

**Analysis:** Not Weaponised. The change is purely technical and does not alter the meaning or introduce any weaponisation of cultural heritage narratives.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last1=John |first1=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community.  The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|COVID-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref> For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=ARHIROVA |first1=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}}</ref>

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] In 2000/2001 [[academic year]], 70% of students attended Ukrainian-language schools (that is where [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in [[Russian language|Russian-language]] schools. There are schools with instruction in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], and [[Polish language|Polish]] in regions populated by those groups. This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -170,7 +170,7 @@ The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".{{Cite web |title=PACE - Resolution 2189 (2017) - The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues |url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=assembly.coe.int}} The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].{{Cite web |title=Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |language=en}} ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.{{cite web |title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF |access-date=30 July 2010 |work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]] |publisher=[[European Union]] |format=PDF}}{{cite web |title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages |url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm |access-date=27 June 2016 |publisher=[[European Commission]]}}) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.{{Cite news |date=2017-10-10 |title=Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 |access-date=2021-12-07}} The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups. PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives. On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine's education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018) -In January 2020 the 2017 education language law was changed and made it legal to teach "one or more disciplines" in "two or more languages – in the official state language, in English, in another official [[languages of the European Union]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/articles/2020/01/17/7105243/|title=Reconciliation schools: do the new language norms rule Ukraine's conflict with Hungary|date=7 January 2020|access-date=29 September 2023|publisher=[[European Pravda]]|language=Ukrainian}} All not state funded schools were made free to choose their own language of instruction. According to the 2020 law until the fifth year of education all lessons can be completely thought in the [[Languages of Ukraine|minority language]] without mandatory teaching of subjects in Ukrainian. In the fifth year not less than 20% of the lessons must be taught in Ukrainian. Then every year the volume of teaching in the state language (Ukrainian) should increase, reaching 40% in the ninth grade. In the twelfth and final year at least 60% of education should be taught in Ukrainian. +In January 2020 the 2017 education language law was changed and made it legal to teach "one or more disciplines" in "two or more languages – in the official state language, in English, in another official [[languages of the European Union]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/articles/2020/01/17/7105243/|title=Reconciliation schools: do the new language norms rule Ukraine's conflict with Hungary|date=7 January 2020|access-date=29 September 2023|publisher=[[European Pravda]]|language=Ukrainian}} All not state funded schools were made free to choose their own language of instruction. According to the 2020 law until the fifth year of education all lessons can be completely taught in the [[Languages of Ukraine|minority language]] without mandatory teaching of subjects in Ukrainian. In the fifth year not less than 20% of the lessons must be taught in Ukrainian. Then every year the volume of teaching in the state language (Ukrainian) should increase, reaching 40% in the ninth grade. In the twelfth and final year at least 60% of education should be taught in Ukrainian. Since the language of instruction in Ukrainian schools is the state language, which is Ukrainian (national minorities are guaranteed the right to study in public educational facilities including their language alongside Ukrainian).[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about?]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine's education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row]
llm_output:
**Change Description:** No changes were made to the content; only a typo was fixed.

**Analysis:** Not Weaponised. The revision is a minor edit focused on correcting a typo and does not introduce any language or narratives that could be considered weaponising cultural heritage.
