changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -126,7 +126,7 @@
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
 {{Main article|Postgraduate education in Ukraine}}
-Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
+Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
@@ -195,7 +195,7 @@
 ==Criticism==
 According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010)</ref> According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science;
 
-Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective  educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers' Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&q=education |isbn=9781443896894 }}</ref>
+Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective  educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers' Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|publisher=Cambridge Scholars |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&q=education |isbn=9781443896894 }}</ref>
 
 In 2013 the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.<ref name=UWBU9713>[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013)</ref>

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -161,7 +161,9 @@
 * "3" = "2+"
 * "2" = "2"
 * "1" = "2-"
+* "0" = "2--"
 Here signs "+" and "-" denote respectively better and worse version of a mark, for example, "4-" means "somewhat worse than good".
+Mark "0" is very rarely given in Ukrainian schools (when student refuses to answer for question or doing any exam or task). This mark can be compared to "2--" (in Russia) and/or "F--" in the USA.
 
 ==Languages used in Educational Establishments<!--Linked from [[Russian language in Ukraine]]-->==
 On 25 September 2017 a new law; the [[Ukrainization#2017 law "On Education"|law "On Education"]]  on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on 5 September 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=2017-09-26 |title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language Bill Into Law |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html |access-date=2020-04-14 |website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |language=en}}</ref> The law makes exceptions for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]], and allows any languages to be taught as separate subjects.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Tulup |first=Margarita |date=2017-12-08 |others=Liz Barnes, translator |title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about? |url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/ |access-date=2020-04-14 |website=openDemocracy |language=en}}</ref> The 2017 law stipulated a three-year transitional period,<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">{{Cite web |title=New education law becomes effective in Ukraine |url=https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=www.unian.info |language=en}}</ref><ref name="law">[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> later extended until 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row |url=https://www.unian.info/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=www.unian.info |language=en}}</ref>
llm_output:
**Added new grading scale entries and context regarding Ukrainian education.** 

The revision introduces additional grading scale entries ("0" and "2--") and provides context about the grading system in Ukrainian schools, particularly in relation to the mark "0" and its comparison to Russian and American grading systems. 

**Not Weaponised**: The changes are primarily factual and educational in nature, focusing on grading systems without invoking politically charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -170,6 +170,8 @@ The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".{{Cite web |title=PACE - Resolution 2189 (2017) - The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues |url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=assembly.coe.int}} The law also faced criticism from officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].{{Cite web |title=Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-language-legislation-minority-languages-russia-hungary-romania/28753925.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |language=en}} ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] are official languages of the European Union, [[Russian language|Russian]] is not.{{cite web |title=Consolidated version of Regulation No 1 determining the languages to be used by the European Economic Community |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1958R0001:20070101:EN:PDF |access-date=30 July 2010 |work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]] |publisher=[[European Union]] |format=PDF}}{{cite web |title=Languages of Europe – Official EU languages |url=http://ec.europa.eu/languages/policy/linguistic-diversity/official-languages-eu_en.htm |access-date=27 June 2016 |publisher=[[European Commission]]}}) Ukrainian officials stressed that the new law complies fully with European norms on minority rights.{{Cite news |date=2017-10-10 |title=Hungary in language dispute with Ukraine over schools |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41565090 |access-date=2021-12-07}} The law does state that "Persons belonging to [[indigenous peoples of Ukraine]] are guaranteed the right to study in public facilities of preschool and primary education in the language of instruction of the respective indigenous people, along with the state language of instruction" in separate classes or groups. PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives. On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine's education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018) +In January 2020 the 2017 education language law was changed and made it legal to teach "one or more disciplines" in "two or more languages – in the official state language, in English, in another official [[languages of the European Union]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/articles/2020/01/17/7105243/|title=Reconciliation schools: do the new language norms rule Ukraine's conflict with Hungary|date=7 January 2020|access-date=29 September 2023|publisher=[[European Pravda]]|language=Ukrainian}} All not state funded schools were made free to choose their own language of instruction. According to the 2020 law until the fifth year of education all lessons can be completely thought in the [[Languages of Ukraine|minority language]] without mandatory teaching of subjects in Ukrainian. In the fifth year not less than 20% of the lessons must be taught in Ukrainian. Then every year the volume of teaching in the state language (Ukrainian) should increase, reaching 40% in the ninth grade. In the twelfth and final year at least 60% of education should be taught in Ukrainian. + Since the language of instruction in Ukrainian schools is the state language, which is Ukrainian (national minorities are guaranteed the right to study in public educational facilities including their language alongside Ukrainian).[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about?]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine's education law not over – minister]
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row] In 2000/2001 [[academic year]], 70% of students attended Ukrainian-language schools (that is where [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] is the primary language of instruction), while 29% were studying in [[Russian language|Russian-language]] schools. There are schools with instruction in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], and [[Polish language|Polish]] in regions populated by those groups.

Not Weaponised. The changes provide factual information about educational policies without employing loaded language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

Minister of Education and Sci. |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = @@ -126,9 +126,9 @@ ===Postgraduate level=== {{Main article|Postgraduate education in Ukraine}} -Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}} +Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer-reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}} After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. -''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions. +''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position associate professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions. The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} ==Marks== @@ -188,14 +188,14 @@ [[File:Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes part in Skovoroda-300 forum in Pereiaslav, speaks with students of three universities. (52717310284).jpg|thumb|Zelenskyy with Ukrainian university students in [[Pereiaslav]] in December 2022]] The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.{{Cite web |last1=John |first1=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}} In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}} -The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|COVID-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}} For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack. Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students. About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.{{Cite web |last1=ARHIROVA |first1=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}} +The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|COVID-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}} For the start of the 2022–2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack. Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students. About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.{{Cite web |last1=ARHIROVA |first1=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}} In January 2023, the [[UNICEF]] said education for more than 5 million children was disrupted by the war in Ukraine. The use of explosive weapons in the conflict destructed thousands of schools and other educational buildings throughout Ukraine, especially those located in densely populated areas. The UNICEF urged for more support to ensure access to offline learning resources and supplies for children.{{cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|title=Ukraine war disrupts education for more than five million children: UNICEF|accessdate=23 January 2023 |website=UN news}} ==Criticism== According to British economist [[Frances Cairncross]] (in April 2010) "Ukrainian education is too inward-looking, too [[Corruption in Ukraine|corrupt]] and too poor to do a good job".[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/education-problems-deeper-than-language-63027.html Education problems deeper than language], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 April 2010) According to Swedish economist [[Anders Åslund]] (in October 2012) the best parts of the Ukrainian education system are basic education in mathematics and science; -Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers' Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|publisher=Cambridge Scholars |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&q=education |isbn=9781443896894 }} +Ukrainian professor {{ill|O. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result, the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers' Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|publisher=Cambridge Scholars |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&q=education |isbn=9781443896894 }} In 2013 the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013) @@ -206,7 +206,7 @@ * [[National Academy of Educational Sciences of Ukraine]] ==References== -{{More footnotes|date=February 2008}} +{{More footnotes needed|date=February 2008}} {{reflist}} == Further reading == @@ -219,5 +219,6 @@ {{Ukraine topics}} {{Education in Europe}}{{2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}} + {{DEFAULTSORT:Study In Ukraine}} [[Category:Education in Ukraine| ]]

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}} +Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}} After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position Associate Professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions. "5", "4", "3" can be described as "Passed", "2" - as "Fail". Students who get a failing grade of "2", have two more chances to pass an examination. Since 2006 (and even earlier in some universities), university students are graded on a rating scale of 0 to 100. These grades can be transformed to the 5-point scale approximately as follows (this system may vary a little from university to university and may change from time to time): -*from 90 to 100 means "5" —– A -*from 74 to 89 means "4" —— B, C -*from 60 to 73 means "3" —— D, E -*from 0 to 59 means "2" —— F +* from 90 to 100 means "5" —– A +* from 74 to 89 means "4" —— B, C +* from 60 to 73 means "3" —— D, E +* from 0 to 59 means "2" —— F Both the rating scale and the 5-point scale are used in university registers. (52717310284).jpg|thumb|Zelenskyy with Ukrainian university students in [[Pereiaslav]] in December 2022]] -The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.{{Cite web |last1=John |first1=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}} In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}} +The education of about 5.5 million children was affected by the war with about 22 schools being attacked daily, per the Save the Children organization and official Ukrainian figures. A survey by the Ukrainian government estimated in June 2022 that 5.7 million school aged children aged between 3 and 18-years-old had been affected by the war and of those 2.8 million were displaced.{{Cite web |last1=John |first1=Tara |last2=Kostenko |first2=Maria |date=August 23, 2022 |title=Bomb shelters, knowledge gaps and the need for community. Six months into the war, Ukrainian schools are reflecting the new reality |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/23/europe/ukraine-schools-six-months-cmd-intl/index.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=CNN}} In early April 2022, it was reported that at least 869 education facilities or about 6% of schools in Ukraine had been damaged, with about 83 completely destroyed and other classroom being used as emergency accommodation. Additionally there was a lack of teachers, which had been a concern prior to the invasion, but majorly teachers were female and became refugees elsewhere with their children.{{Cite news |last=Dasey |first=Jason |date=2022-04-05 |title=Russia attacking more than 20 schools a day in Ukraine, Save the Children says |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-06/20-schools-a-day-attacked-in-ukraine-war-as-children-suffer/100968128 |access-date=2022-04-25}} The Ukrainian government paused all education for a few days when the war first broke out, before returning to online learning that had been the precedent from the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine|COVID-19 pandemic]], with some schools re-opening in person teaching by May 2022 in less affected areas.{{Cite news |last=Jozwiak |first=Gabriella |date=2022-08-30 |title=Metal bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235}} For the start of the 2022-2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack. Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students. About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.{{Cite web |last1=ARHIROVA |first1=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en}} @@ -196,8 +196,8 @@ In 2013 the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013) ==See also== -*[[List of universities in Ukraine]] -*[[National Accreditation Agency of Ukraine]] +* [[List of universities in Ukraine]] +* [[National Accreditation Agency of Ukraine]] * [[Open access in Ukraine]] to scholarly communication * [[National Academy of Educational Sciences of Ukraine]]

bars, heavy sandbags and air raid shelters – the battle to reopen schools in Ukraine |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |access-date=2022-09-01 |issn=0307-1235 |archive-date=2022-08-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220831204300/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/terror-and-security/metal-bars-heavy-sandbags-air-raid-shelters-battle-reopen/ |url-status=live }}</ref> For the start of the 2022–2023 academic year many Ukrainian schools attempted to re-open for the school year, however many are heavily damaged from the war and lack safe locations for pupils and educators if the buildings come under attack.<ref name=":1" /> Per government regulations a schools shelter should be preferably be large enough to allow for the continuation of lessons, but if they cannot hold all enrolled pupils then the schools should offer part-time onsite and online learning for all enrolled students.<ref name=":2" /> About 51% of the schools in Ukraine planned to return to in-person education with online study if the parents preferred it, with any school without quick access to shelters or located close to borders with Russia or Belarus staying virtual.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=ARHIROVA |first1=HANNA |last2=FISCH |first2=YESICA |date=September 1, 2022 |title=It's back to school in Ukraine — but far from normal |url=https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |access-date=2022-09-01 |website=Idaho State Journal |language=en |archive-date=2022-09-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220906073520/https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/world/its-back-to-school-in-ukraine-but-far-from-normal/article_3a5868e9-890a-59bd-a244-eb10773b73e4.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>
 
+In 2022 works by [[Russian authors|Russian]] and [[Soviet authors]] were removed from the foreign literature curriculum of Ukrainian schools.<ref>{{Cite web |date=16 June 2022|title=Pushkin, Tolstoy, Lermontov, and other russian authors will not be studied in Ukrainian schools|url=https://imi.org.ua/en/news/pushkin-tolstoy-lermontov-and-other-russian-authors-will-not-be-studied-in-ukrainian-schools-i46266 |accessdate=5 September 2024|website={{ill|Institute of Mass Information|uk|Інститут масової інформації}}|language=English}}</ref>
+
 In January 2023, the [[UNICEF]] said education for more than 5 million children was disrupted by the war in Ukraine. The use of explosive weapons in the conflict destructed thousands of schools and other educational buildings throughout Ukraine, especially those located in densely populated areas. The UNICEF urged for more support to ensure access to offline learning resources and supplies for children.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|title=Ukraine war disrupts education for more than five million children: UNICEF|accessdate=23 January 2023|website=UN news|archive-date=24 January 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230124001421/https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/01/1132757|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Criticism==
comment: /* During the Russian invasion */In 2022 works by [[Russian authors|Russian]] and [[Soviet authors]] were removed from the foreign literature curriculum of [[Education in Ukraine|Ukrainian schools]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=16 June 2022|title=Pushkin, Tolstoy, Lermontov, and other russian authors will not be studied in Ukrainian schools|url=https://imi.org.ua/en/news/pushkin-tolstoy-lermontov-and-other-russian-authors-will-not-be-studied-in-ukrainian-schools-i46266 |accessdate=5 September 2024|w...
llm_output:
Added a statement about the removal of works by Russian and Soviet authors from the foreign literature curriculum of Ukrainian schools.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides factual information about educational changes in Ukraine during the conflict without employing weaponised language or narratives.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -182,6 +182,8 @@
 The initial policies of the [[Bolsheviks]] were supportive of local languages, and many Ukrainian-language schools were opened, with the long-term goal of getting rid of illiteracy. From the mid-1930s to the mid-1980s, the Soviet government policies favoured [[Russification]]. In the 1970s and 1980s, the number of Russian-language schools constantly increased at the expense of Ukrainian-language schools. After Ukraine obtained independence the trend was reversed. However, reintroduction of formal Ukrainian-language study has taken longer than expected. In some schools that have tried to switch to Ukrainian, part or most of the instruction is still given in Russian.
 In universities there are similar trends. In 1991/92 [[academic year]], according to the [[Razumkov Centre]], 49% of high school students were receiving their education in Ukrainian, and 50% in Russian.
 
+As of 2024, the number of secondary schools in which education takes place exclusively in the Ukrainian language, in 2023 was 12,155 - 98.4%. In addition, 3,834,708 students - 99.1% - study Ukrainian. 447 schoolchildren (0.01%) continue to study in Russian at the level of the state language. In the 2022/2023 academic year, there were 1,362 of them. In 2022, the number of students studying Russian in schools decreased more than 100 times: from 454,800 in September 2021 to about 4,000 as of September 1, 2022. In 2023/2024, the number of schoolchildren studying the Russian language as a separate subject decreased another 5 times - to 768. The Russian language continues to be taught in 3 schools in Ukraine.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|access-date=2024-06-23|lang=uk|title=In some schools of Ukraine, the Russian language is still studied as a separate subject: the report of the language ombudsman|url=https://life.pravda.com.ua/society/rosiysku-movu-v-ukrajini-vivchayut-menshe-nizh-800-uchniv-zvit-movnogo-ombudsmena-301344/|website=Українська правда. Життя}}</ref>
+
 ==Education of international students==
 [[Ukraine]] is a popular destination for education among Asian and African students. There are more than 63,000 students from 130 countries of the world now.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.segodnya.ua/economics/enews/ukraina-zarabatyvaet-na-inostrannyh-studentah-po-500-mln-v-god-660428.html|title=Украина зарабатывает на иностранных студентах $500 млн в год|date=July 11, 2022|website=segodnya.ua}}</ref> A lot of non-government companies try to help students from all over the world apply to one of the universities in Ukraine. An example of this is the [[Ukrainian Educational Agency]].<ref>[http://www.uea.co.ua Ukrainian Educational Agency]</ref>
llm_output:
**Added statistics regarding the current state of Ukrainian and Russian language education in schools.**

Weaponised. The addition of detailed statistics about the decline of Russian language education in Ukraine and the emphasis on Ukrainian language education reflects a narrative that may be used to assert cultural dominance and highlight the suppression of Russian language and culture in the context of ongoing tensions.

Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer-reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}} +Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer-reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}} + After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade. ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position associate professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. PACE describes this as a significant curtailing of the rights of indigenous peoples carried out without consultations with their representatives. On 27 June 2018 Ukrainian foreign minister [[Pavlo Klimkin]] stated that following the recommendation of the [[Venice Commission]] the language provision of the (September 2017) law on education will not apply to private schools and that every public school for national minorities "will have broad powers to independently determine which classes will be taught in Ukrainian or their native language."[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10167494-hungary-realizes-ukraine-not-to-change-education-law-klimkin.html Hungary realizes Ukraine not to change education law – Klimkin], [[UNIAN]] (27 June 2018)[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/2342342-debate-on-language-provisions-of-ukraines-education-law-not-over-minister.html Debate on language provisions of Ukraine's education law not over – minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018) -In January 2020 the 2017 education language law was changed and made it legal to teach "one or more disciplines" in "two or more languages – in the official state language, in English, in another official [[languages of the European Union]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/articles/2020/01/17/7105243/|title=Reconciliation schools: do the new language norms rule Ukraine's conflict with Hungary|date=7 January 2020|access-date=29 September 2023|publisher=[[European Pravda]]|language=Ukrainian}} All not state funded schools were made free to choose their own language of instruction. According to the 2020 law until the fifth year of education all lessons can be completely taught in the [[Languages of Ukraine|minority language]] without mandatory teaching of subjects in Ukrainian. In the fifth year not less than 20% of the lessons must be taught in Ukrainian. Then every year the volume of teaching in the state language (Ukrainian) should increase, reaching 40% in the ninth grade. In the twelfth and final year at least 60% of education should be taught in Ukrainian. +In January 2020, the 2017 education language law was changed and made it legal to teach "one or more disciplines" in "two or more languages – in the official state language, in English, in another official [[languages of the European Union]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/articles/2020/01/17/7105243/|title=Reconciliation schools: do the new language norms rule Ukraine's conflict with Hungary|date=7 January 2020|access-date=29 September 2023|publisher=[[European Pravda]]|language=Ukrainian}} All not state funded schools were made free to choose their own language of instruction. Bazaluk|uk|Базалук Олег Олександрович}} reports that the Ukrainian education provides for a student nothing more than an illusion of training. As a result, the majority of the Ukrainian graduates do not possess even a basic level of professional knowledge when they leave their schools. Due to extremely ineffective educational policy of the Ukrainian government and ubiquitous [[Corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] the everyday life of the society has been significantly changed. The new developed qualities of the social transformation include aggression, rudeness, intolerance, boastfulness, reticence etc.{{cite book |last=Bazaluk|first=Oleg|date=2016 |title= Corruption in Ukraine: Rulers' Mentality and the Destiny of the Nation|pages=XI|chapter= Introduction|publisher=Cambridge Scholars |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weH6DAAAQBAJ&q=education |isbn=9781443896894 }} -In 2013 the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013) +In 2013, the education system received the third highest percentage among Ukrainians of having given a [[Corruption in Ukraine|bribe]] too with 33%.[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013) ==See also== * [[List of universities in Ukraine]]

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

{{stub}}


[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -126,7 +126,7 @@
 
 ===Postgraduate level===
 {{Main article|Postgraduate education in Ukraine}}
-Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer-reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]].|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
+Upon obtaining a master's degree or Specialist, a student may enter a university or a scientific institute to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' that usually results in the ''Kandydat Nauk'' degree ([[Candidate of Sciences]]). Candidates must pass three or more qualifying exams (one or more in the field of specialty, one in a foreign language of their choice and one in philosophy), publish at least five papers in peer-reviewed journals (according to requirements existed up to 2013 they had to publish at least three papers), write a [[dissertation]] and defend it. This degree is roughly equivalent to the [[Ph.D.]] in the United States.<ref name="GSE">{{cite book|title=[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia|Great Soviet Encyclopedia.]]|publisher=Sovetskaya Enciklopediya|edition=3rd|location=Moscow|language=ru|no-pp=true|page=Vol. 11}}</ref>
 After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. This takes from two to four years of study in ''doctorantura''. Significant scientific results must be obtained and published, and a new thesis written. This produces a ''[[Doktor nauk|Doctor Nauk]]'' degree (Doctor of Sciences), but the more typical way is working in a university or scientific institute with parallel preparation of a thesis. The average time between obtaining ''[[Kandidat]]'' and ''Doctor'' degrees is roughly 10 years, and most of new ''Doctors'' are 40 and more years old. Only one of four ''Kandidats'' reaches this grade.
 ''Kandidat Nauk'' may keep the position associate professor in universities, or Researcher/Senior Researcher in scientific institutes. ''Doctor Nauk'' can hold position of full Professor, Head of Laboratory or an equal/higher positions.
 The Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science is considering changing the Soviet style ''Kandidat Nauk'' and ''Doctor Nauk'' degrees to Doctor of Philosophy and Doctor Habilitation, as has happened in several other post-Soviet countries. {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}

Not Weaponised. The change is purely editorial and does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

[[Category:Education in Ukraine|*]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -100,7 +100,7 @@
 The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine'']</ref> The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian history, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music, and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], drama, learning folktales and folk songs, choir, and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, football, hockey, or tennis.<ref>Kummer, Patricia K. (2001) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ Ukraine Enchantment of the World] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191028182233/https://www.amazon.com/dp/0516211013/ |date=2019-10-28 }}</ref>
 [[File:2013. Донецк 336.jpg|thumb|265px|Knowledge Day in [[Donetsk]], 2013]]
 
-During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. In grades 9 and 12 students take Independent Government Tests (IGTs), which allows eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008, entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання...| від 24.01.2008<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191028182227/https://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08 |date=2019-10-28 }} {{in lang|uk}}</ref> However, the system was changed again in 2010.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
+During grades 9 and 12, which is usually around the age of 15 and 17, students take various exams. The current examination system is undergoing change. In grades 9 and 12 students take Independent Government Tests (IGTs), which allows eleventh graders to enter university without taking separate entrance exams. In 2008, entrance exams were abolished and the IGTs became the standard for determining entrance eligibility.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20191028182227/https://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=z0073-08|url-status=dead|title=Про затвердження Порядку проведення зовнішнього незалежного оцінювання навчальних досягнень випускників навчальних закладів системи загальної середньої освіти|archivedate=October 28, 2019|website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України}}</ref> However, the system was changed again in 2010.<!--It's necessary to write more about this, but I don't know details and don't want to look for.-->
 
 In [[school year]] 2009-2010 potential graduates are scheduled to undergo external independent testing after the final state examination, in the following subjects: [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature|literature]], [[history of Ukraine]], [[mathematics]], [[biology]], [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[geography]], and one foreign language (of the pupil's choice) in either [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], or [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The results of the testing will have the same status as entrance examinations to institutions of higher education.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50275 School leavers to have external independent testing after state final examination], [[Kyiv Post]] (8 October 2009) {{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> But some universities can convert points in the external independent test certificate according to their own rating system.

+Starting in September 2018, children who start school have 12 years of education, while those already in school complete their studying by 11-year system.<ref name="tulupneweducation">{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law|title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about? | openDemocracy|access-date=2018-02-15|archive-date=2018-02-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180215204245/https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/margarita-tulup/ukraines-new-education-law|url-status=live}}</ref> As a rule, schooling begins at the age of 6, unless your birthday is on or after 1 September.<ref>Bassis/Dhilawala. (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World:Ukraine'' p.72]</ref>  In 2016/17, the number of students in primary and secondary school reached 3,846,000, in vocational school 285,800, and in higher education 1,586,700 students. According to 2017 EduConf speech of the (then) Minister of Education and Science of Ukraine, [[Liliya Hrynevych]], the amount of budget financing for the sphere of education would reach about ₴53 billion in 2017 (compared to 42 in 2016).<ref name="tulupneweducation" />
 
 The [[NGO]] [[Human Rights Measurement Initiative]] in the spring of 2022 concluded that Ukraine is fulfilling 84.2% of what they should be fulfilling on the right to education, based on their level of income.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukraine - HRMI Rights Tracker |url=https://rightstracker.org/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=rightstracker.org |language=en |archive-date=2022-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220324233849/https://rightstracker.org/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

llm_output:
Changed the phrasing from "12-year secondary education will replace 11-year which was mandatory before that" to "children who start school have 12 years of education, while those already in school complete their studying by 11-year system."

Not Weaponised. The change improves clarity without introducing any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
This article is about '''[[education]] in [[Ukraine]]'''.

==General information==
Ukraine's educational system has produced nearly 100% literacy.

==Major universities==
*[[National Technical University of Ukraine]]
*[[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev]]
*[[Kharkiv National University]]
*[[Donetsk National University]]

==Ukrainian educational system==
Simiralry to [[Education in Russia|Russian educational system]], Ukriane's one may be arranged into three major groups: secondary education, higher education, and postgraduate education. 

Since 2005 12-year school system was introduced in Unkraine: primary education takes 4 years to complete (engaging six-year-old children), middle education takes 5 years to complete, depending on the school. And then there are 3 profile years. Full secondary education is compulsory for all Ukrainian citizens. 

The higher education can be obtained at the expense of either state budget or own. It is common practice that an university entrant doesn't need to pass entrance examination to enter university if he/she will study at the his/her own expense (actually there are some examsbut they are formal only).

Students that study at the expense of state receive scholarship of 136 [[hryvnia]]s if their average mark of end-of-term exams ("sessiya" - "сессия") and differentiated test ("differensirovannyi zachot" – "дифференцированный зачёт") is 4 to 4.99. In case of 5 average the scholarship is increased to 170 [[hryvnia]]s.

There are three different degrees that are conferred by Ukrainian universities: Bachelor's Degree (4 years), Specialist's Degree (5–6 years), and Master's Degree (6 years). Bachelor's and Master's degrees were introduced relatively recently; they did not exist in the Soviet Union. As Unkraine is taking part in [[Bologna process]] they will eventually replace Specialist's Degree.

After obtaining a Specialist's or Master's Degree, a student may enter a University to pursue postgraduate education. The first level of postgraduate education is ''aspirantura'' ({{lang|ru|аспирантура}}) that usually results in the Candidate of Sciences Degree ({{lang|ru|кандидат наук}}). This degree is roughly equivalent to the Ph.D. in the United States.  After graduation a student may continue postgraduate education. Four years of study would result in the Doctor's Degree ({{lang|ru|доктор наук}}) . A Candidate of Sciences Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of assistant professor and a Doctor's Degree may be accompanied by honorary degree of professor.

===Marks===

Ukrainian univesities use traditional 5-grade scale:
"5" = excellent,
"4" = good,
"3" = acceptable,
"2" = "unacceptable" (Fail).

If student gets "2" he/she has 3 chances to resit an examination.

Since 2001 schools use 12-grade scale:  
*"12" = "5+"
*"11" = "5"
*"10" = "5-"
*"9" = "4+"
*"8" = "4"
*"7" = "4-"
*"6" = "3+"
*"5" = "3"
*"4" = "3-"
*"3" = "2+"
*"2" = "2"
*"1" = "2-"

==See also==
{{Education by country}}
*[[List of universities in Ukraine]]

==External links==
*{{uk icon}} [http://www.mon.gov.ua Official website of the Ministry of Education and Science of the Ukraine]

 ==Languages used in Educational Establishments<!--Linked from [[Russian language in Ukraine]]-->==
 On 25 September 2017 a new law; the [[Ukrainization#2017 law "On Education"|law "On Education"]]  on education was signed by President Poroshenko (draft approved by Rada on 5 September 2017) which will make [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] the language of education from the fifth grade on.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=2017-09-26 |title=Ukrainian President Signs Controversial Language Bill Into Law |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html |access-date=2020-04-14 |website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |language=en |archive-date=2022-02-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220220203800/https://www.rferl.org/a/ukrainian-poroshenko-signs-controversial-language-bill-into-law/28757195.html |url-status=live }}</ref> The law makes exceptions for one or more subjects that are allowed to be taught in two or more languages, namely [[English language|English]] or one of the other [[official languages of the European Union]], and allows any languages to be taught as separate subjects.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Tulup |first=Margarita |date=2017-12-08 |others=Liz Barnes, translator |title=Beyond the scandal: what is Ukraine's new education law really about? |url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/ |access-date=2020-04-14 |website=openDemocracy |language=en |archive-date=2020-02-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200226120612/https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/ukraines-new-education-law/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The 2017 law stipulated a three-year transitional period,<ref name="UNIAN 2159231">{{Cite web |title=New education law becomes effective in Ukraine |url=https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=www.unian.info |language=en |archive-date=2018-06-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180627202400/https://www.unian.info/society/2159231-new-education-law-becomes-effective-in-ukraine.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="law">[http://zakon2.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page Про освіту] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214235416/https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2145-19/page |date=2021-02-14 }} | від 05.09.2017 № 2145-VIII (Сторінка 1 з 7)</ref> later extended until 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukraine agrees to concessions to Hungary in language row |url=https://www.unian.info/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=www.unian.info |language=en |archive-date=2021-02-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214235423/https://www.unian.info/politics/2395156-ukraine-agrees-to-concessions-to-hungary-in-language-row.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
-The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it "a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities".<ref name="PACE">{{Cite web |title=PACE - Resolution 2189 (2017) - The new Ukrainian law on education: a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities' mother tongues |url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-EN.asp?fileid=24218&lang=en |access-date=2021-12-07 |website=assembly.coe.int |archive-date=2017-10-13 officials in [[Hungary]], [[Romania]] and [[Russia]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukrainian Language Bill Facing Barrage Of Criticism From Minorities, Foreign Capitals [[UNIAN]] (12 January 2018)</ref>

llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of the sentence: "The law was condemned by [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] that called it 'a major impediment to the teaching of national minorities'." 

Weaponised

This addition highlights criticism of Ukraine's education law, framing it as a significant issue regarding the rights of national minorities. This aligns with narratives that can be used to portray Ukraine's policies as oppressive, which may serve to weaponize cultural heritage discussions in the context of minority rights.

the right to education, based on their level of income.{{Cite web |title=Ukraine - HRMI Rights Tracker |url=https://rightstracker.org/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=rightstracker.org |language=en class="wikitable" style="line-height:0.9em; border:1px black; float:right; margin-left:1em" @@ -97,14 +97,14 @@ Primary and secondary education is divided into three levels of accreditation of general education: I - "younger", II - "middle", and III - "senior". Level 1 comprises grades 1 to 4. Grades 5-9 are usually considered a II level of accreditation or a base secondary education, while 10-12 are a III level. Despite the names, students usually study in the same school throughout their primary and secondary education. [[Primary school|Elementary school]]ing lasts for 4 years, [[middle school]] for 5 and [[Secondary school|high school]] for 3. -The objective of general schooling is to give younger students knowledge of the arts and sciences, and teach them how to use it practically.Bassis/Dhilawala (2009). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0761420908 ''Cultures of the World: Ukraine''] The middle school curriculum includes classes in the [[Ukrainian language]], [[Ukrainian Literature]], a foreign language, world literature, Ukrainian history, world history, [[geography]], [[algebra]], [[geometry]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[physical education]], music, and art. At some schools, students also take environment and [[civics]] classes. Students attend each class only once or twice a week. Part of the school day is also spent in activities such as [[chess]], [[karate]], drama, learning folktales and folk songs, choir, and band. After school, students might also have music lessons, football, hockey, or tennis.Kummer, Patricia K.
